content.title: Acute Respiratory Failure
content.summary: Acute respiratory failure is the inability to maintain adequate gas exchange with sudden onset, classified as hypoxemic (Type 1), hypercapnic (Type 2), or combined, requiring systematic evaluation of etiology and appropriate ventilatory support.
key_points: Type 1 (hypoxemic): PaO2 <60 mmHg on room air; caused by V/Q mismatch, shunt, or diffusion impairment
Type 2 (hypercapnic): PaCO2 >45 mmHg; caused by inadequate alveolar ventilation
P/F ratio (PaO2/FiO2) <300 indicates respiratory failure; <200 is severe
Workload vs capacity mismatch - respiratory failure occurs when demand exceeds supply
Treatment targets underlying cause while providing supportive ventilation
Escalating support: oxygen, HFNC, NIV, invasive mechanical ventilation, ECMO
content.statement: Acute respiratory failure is the sudden inability to maintain adequate oxygenation, ventilation, or both, classified as Type 1 (hypoxemic - PaO2 <60 mmHg), Type 2 (hypercapnic - PaCO2 >45 mmHg with acidemia), or combined, requiring prompt identification of the underlying etiology and appropriate respiratory support.

explanation.intuition: The lungs have two jobs: bring oxygen in and get carbon dioxide out. When either function fails acutely, it's respiratory failure. Type 1 is an oxygenation problem (oxygen isn't getting into the blood), while Type 2 is a ventilation problem (CO2 isn't being blown off). Understanding which type helps guide both the workup and the treatment.
explanation.key_insight: Think of respiratory failure as a balance between supply and demand. The respiratory muscles are the pump; the demand is set by metabolism, dead space, and airway resistance. Failure occurs when the pump can't meet demand - either because demand is too high (work of breathing) or supply is too low (muscle weakness, drive issues).
explanation.technical_details: Hypoxemia mechanisms: V/Q mismatch (responds to supplemental O2), shunt (doesn't respond well), diffusion limitation (exercise, altitude), hypoventilation (corrects with ventilation). Hypercapnia occurs when VE < VCO2 production + dead space. The alveolar gas equation relates PAO2 to FiO2 and PaCO2. A-a gradient helps distinguish parenchymal from non-parenchymal causes.

definitions_glossary.acute_respiratory_failure: Sudden onset inability to maintain adequate oxygenation or ventilation requiring intervention
definitions_glossary.type_1_respiratory_failure: Hypoxemic failure with PaO2 <60 mmHg on room air; primary oxygenation problem
definitions_glossary.type_2_respiratory_failure: Hypercapnic failure with PaCO2 >45 mmHg and pH <7.35; primary ventilation problem
definitions_glossary.pao2_fio2_ratio: Ratio of arterial oxygen tension to inspired oxygen fraction; index of oxygenation severity
definitions_glossary.hypoxemia: Low arterial oxygen tension (PaO2 <60 mmHg or SpO2 <90%)
definitions_glossary.ventilation_perfusion_mismatch: Imbalance between alveolar ventilation and pulmonary blood flow causing hypoxemia
definitions_glossary.intrapulmonary_shunt: Perfusion without ventilation; blood passes through non-ventilated lung units
definitions_glossary.alveolar_ventilation: Volume of gas reaching alveoli per minute; determines CO2 elimination
definitions_glossary.dead_space_ventilation: Ventilation of areas without perfusion; wastes respiratory effort
definitions_glossary.work_of_breathing: Energy expenditure for respiratory muscle contraction against elastic and resistive loads
definitions_glossary.a_a_gradient: Alveolar-arterial oxygen difference; helps identify cause of hypoxemia

type_1_mechanisms.vq_mismatch: Areas with low V/Q contribute to hypoxemia; responds to increased FiO2
type_1_mechanisms.shunt: V/Q = 0 (perfusion without ventilation); refractory to supplemental oxygen
type_1_mechanisms.diffusion_impairment: Rare except in exercise or altitude; interstitial disease
type_1_mechanisms.low_inspired_o2: High altitude or enclosed space oxygen depletion

type_2_mechanisms.neuromuscular: Myasthenia, GBS, spinal cord injury, diaphragm paralysis
type_2_mechanisms.airway_obstruction: Severe COPD, asthma, upper airway obstruction

by_gas_abnormality.type_1: PaO2 <60 mmHg; normal or low PaCO2
by_gas_abnormality.combined: Both hypoxemia and hypercapnia; often severe disease

by_onset.acute: Hours to days; little physiologic compensation
by_onset.chronic: Weeks to years; metabolic compensation (chronic CO2 retention)
by_onset.acute_on_chronic: Acute exacerbation of chronic respiratory failure

clinical_assessment.symptoms: Dyspnea, tachypnea, accessory muscle use, altered mental status, cyanosis
clinical_assessment.vital_signs: Tachypnea, tachycardia, hypotension in severe cases
clinical_assessment.physical_exam: Lung sounds, chest wall motion, neurological status

arterial_blood_gas.interpretation: PaO2, PaCO2, pH, HCO3 define type and acuity
arterial_blood_gas.a_a_gradient: PAO2 - PaO2; elevated suggests parenchymal disease

additional_workup.imaging: CXR, CT chest for parenchymal disease

supportive_therapy.supplemental_o2: Nasal cannula, face mask, non-rebreather for hypoxemia
supportive_therapy.high_flow_nasal_cannula: Up to 60 L/min with heated/humidified oxygen
supportive_therapy.non_invasive_ventilation: CPAP/BiPAP for selected patients; especially Type 2 failure
supportive_therapy.invasive_ventilation: Intubation and mechanical ventilation when non-invasive fails
supportive_therapy.ecmo: Extracorporeal support for refractory respiratory failure

treat_underlying_cause.infection: Antibiotics for pneumonia; antivirals when indicated
treat_underlying_cause.neuromuscular: Plasmapheresis/IVIG for GBS; treat myasthenia crisis

skos.definition: The sudden inability to maintain adequate oxygenation (Type 1) or ventilation (Type 2), requiring identification of underlying etiology and appropriate respiratory support.

learning_objectives: Classify respiratory failure as Type 1, Type 2, or combined
Identify pathophysiologic mechanisms of hypoxemia and hypercapnia
Interpret arterial blood gases in the context of respiratory failure
Apply the A-a gradient to differentiate causes of hypoxemia
Select appropriate respiratory support based on failure type
Recognize indications for escalation of respiratory support
clinical_pearls: P/F ratio is a quick bedside assessment - <300 is respiratory failure, <200 is severe
If hypoxemia doesn't improve with high FiO2, think shunt (atelectasis, consolidation, ARDS)
A-a gradient helps distinguish lung disease (elevated) from hypoventilation (normal gradient)
In COPD exacerbation, look at pH not just CO2 - chronic retainers tolerate high CO2 with normal pH
Work of breathing is as important as gas exchange - treat before the patient tires out
Type 2 failure from neuromuscular weakness may present with paradoxical abdominal motion

board_yield.usmle_step1: Oxygen dissociation curve, V/Q ratios, alveolar gas equation
board_yield.usmle_step2: ABG interpretation, failure classification, initial management
board_yield.usmle_step3: NIV vs invasive ventilation decision, ARDS management
board_yield.abim_critical_care: Detailed physiology, ventilator strategies, weaning criteria

common_misconceptions: Misconception: Hypoxemia always indicates lung disease. Reality: Hypoventilation from CNS or neuromuscular causes causes hypoxemia with normal A-a gradient
Misconception: High FiO2 always corrects hypoxemia. Reality: Shunt physiology is refractory to supplemental oxygen
Misconception: Normal SpO2 means adequate ventilation. Reality: Patient can have normal O2 but severe CO2 retention

evidence.confidence_rationale: Foundational critical care concept with well-established pathophysiology
